含义: The character '臣' means 'minister' or 'official'. It refers to a person who serves a ruler or a state in an official capacity.
字形: The character '臣' is composed of a single radical, which is itself. It resembles a kneeling figure, symbolizing submission or service.
读音: The pronunciation of '臣' is 'chén' in Mandarin.
字源: The character '臣' originated from ancient pictographs depicting a kneeling figure, symbolizing a servant or minister in the presence of a ruler.
成语: 臣心如水 (chén xīn rú shuǐ)
臣门如市 (chén mén rú shì)
臣颜厚如 (chén yán hòu rú)
例句: 臣愿为陛下效劳。 (Chén yuàn wèi bìxià xiàoláo.) - I am willing to serve Your Majesty.
臣不敢有违君命。 (Chén bù gǎn yǒu wéi jūn mìng.) - I dare not disobey your command.
短故事: In ancient China, a loyal minister named Zhuge Liang served the state of Shu Han. Despite his high position, he remained humble and dedicated to his ruler, Liu Bei, and later his son, Liu Shan. His loyalty and wisdom are celebrated in Chinese history.

Another story involves the minister Bao Zheng, known for his integrity and justice. He served the Song Dynasty and was famous for his impartial judgments, earning the title 'Bao Qingtian' (Bao the Clear Sky).
诗词: 《出师表》 by 诸葛亮 (Zhuge Liang): '臣本布衣，躬耕于南阳。' (Chén běn bùyī, gōng gēng yú Nányáng.) - 'I was originally a commoner, tilling the fields in Nanyang.'
《满江红》 by 岳飞 (Yue Fei): '臣心一片磁针石，不指南方不肯休。' (Chén xīn yī piàn cízhēnshí, bù zhǐ nánfāng bù kěn xiū.) - 'My heart is like a compass needle, never resting until it points south.'
